mc_pro_critic_reviews.summary: Terminator Genisys fires on all action cylinders when director Alan Taylor (Thor: The Dark World) follows the model James Cameron set in the first two films, still the glory of the series.

The best one-liners, like the best fight scenes, are reserved for Schwarzenegger.  It's too soon to tell whether Terminator Genisys will have a catch phrase like "I'll be back" or "Hasta la vista, baby" but there are several candidates. Much of the film's comedy results from The Terminator's failed attempts to emulate human behavior.

What’s remarkable is that this fifth Terminator is worthwhile precisely because of its franchise cash-in excessiveness. It’s at once an eminently satisfying actioner, jackknifing tractor-trailers and vertiginous helicopter chases and all, as it is a passably thought-provoking comment on memory – headily engaging with the very nostalgia it intends to evoke.
This new Terminator, the first since the dreadfully dreary and Arnold-less "Salvation," is engineered to feel at once eerily familiar and raise-the-stakes fresh.
Genisys goes back to what made the franchise work in the first place: not the machine inside the man, but vice versa.
Fresh cast, fresh ideas and full-on action gives Taylor’s reboot momentum, even if an overloaded script threatens to topple it at times. Doesn’t touch Cameron’s two movies, of course.
Genisys is more entertaining than the last two installments, although it's not nearly as good as the first two.

Terminator Genisys is a reasonably entertaining and niftily executed sci-fi action-thriller, and yet its ingenuity and craftsmanship are all in service of justifying its existence, resulting in a sequel that can be appreciated for its cleverness but otherwise regarded with a certain amount of ambivalence.

Terminator: Genisys isn't so much a sequel or a reboot but a piece of fan fiction come to ludicrous, big-budget life. Even for an unnecessary entry in a series of movies about indestructible time-traveling robots and genocidal computer networks, it's pretty silly.

The ultra-tangled plotline of Terminator Genisys makes the rhythm of the action beats especially weird; we see the entire world nuked into rubble by the machine overlords really early in the movie, which makes it hard to get excited about a few buildings falling down later on.

Schwarzenegger has turned into your elderly uncle, dancing like a goofball at your wedding after a couple glasses of champagne. He knows he’s being silly, and he knows that you know, and that alone is supposed to be good for a laugh. But it’s not. It’s just sad. He has essentially become McBain.
This mash-up movie is like a greatest-hits collection for obsessive collectors. On its own terms, Terminator Genisys makes virtually no sense.
For all its weaknesses, Terminator Genisys is a "Terminator" movie that feels like a "Terminator" movie, more than did "Terminator 3," not to mention the ghastly "Terminator Salvation."

The best thing in the movie is Schwarzenegger, who delivers the Guardian’s lines with perfect timing and creates an empathetic character, because as we know, nearly all the best movie robots somehow become just a little bit human as time goes on.
"I'll be back," the man said, and he kept the promise, but I'm not sure we wanted him back like this.
[JK Simmons] provides a little comic relief, and sums up my feelings on this whole outing: “Goddamn time-travelin’ robots!”

The fifth installment of the Terminator series cannot overcome the weight of its convoluted time travel leaps, its strained attempts at injecting twists everywhere, a clunky opening, and a painfully clumsy finish.
Someone describes the T-800 as "nothing but a relic from a deleted timeline." Too harsh to lay on Schwarzenegger yet, but certainly it applies to the Terminator franchise.

Schwarzenegger, weathered and ironic, strides through the film with old-fashioned authority. Except for Clarke, who walks an ambiguous line between heroism and sinister monomania, only Big Arnie leaves the slightest impression after the credits roll.
The story isn’t just confusing, it’s a betrayal to anyone who’s invested brain cells in the Terminatorverse over the past 31 years.
Terminator Genisys' ambition overrides sense and depth in the pursuit of a new direction, and then unwittingly proves how little life there is left in this franchise.
Director Alan Taylor handles the big action adeptly as he did in Thor The Dark World, but the script is an ever-decreasing cycle of tool-ups, chase sequences and daft monologues.
Genisys is all bullets and bombs, action without pause, as though if the ride stops the whole thing will collapse under its own weight.

In practice, the interplay between events old and new is equal parts tedious and indecipherable, with the characters talking about parallel timelines like studio executives thrashing out a franchise in a boardroom.
Salvation was boring, but Genisys makes you sad. Risk-averse Hollywood has made a crash-test dummy of a once great franchise, simply throwing everything at it to see what it stands.

Fans hoping to watch Schwarzenegger growl his catchphrases with a slight edge of shtick are underestimating the patience involved in sitting through a two-hour slog. As for those who want a little apocalyptic tension or (dare to dream) romance, this new model is not for you. It’s the Skynet cut.

The setpieces, in addition to mostly rehashing better scenes from earlier films, feel thrown together to serve the effects, and the effects look far less astonishing than anything in Cameron’s first two films.

The stunts and CGI and attendant action scenes are all simply fine; there’s nothing here with the stark simple power of “The Terminator” or the strong-but-strange brilliant inventions of “Terminator 2.” Instead, it’s all less-than-spectacular “spectacle” and plot convolutions twisting around themselves at the whim of the summer’s least interesting killer artificial intelligence.
For all its initial playfulness, the script never rises to the level of surreal, cortex-tickling pleasure it seems to be aiming for, and for all its self-awareness it’s weirdly devoid of humor.
Terminator Genisys feels like being trapped in a conversation with a child breathlessly recounting the highlights of the preceding movies.
Terminator used to be a sci-fi franchise defined by its cool time-travel concept and even better special effects. Unfortunately, it's "Hasta la vista, baby," to those good old days.
Everything's at stake yet nothing comes to much in Terminator Genisys.
It doesn’t jell, though, and the movie’s philosophical message is especially grating.

Terminator: Genisys is a catastrophic misfire on nearly all counts. It’s only saving grace? 2015 Oscar winner J.K. Simmons (Whiplash) as a Mulder-gone-to-pot-esque cop who believes in these “goddamn time-traveling robots.”
Terminator Genisys could be Exhibit A in why the current line of thinking in Hollywood regarding sequels/reboots/remakes often leads to terrible decisions and worse films.
It’s amusing to see identical Arnolds clash like titans, but nobody here seems to have fully grasped that they had another heavyweight in Mr. Clarke.
Action scenes are accumulated as if mandated by a stop-watch and almost invariably seem like warmed-over versions of stuff we've seen before, in Terminator entries and elsewhere.

When you’ve already put two sequels to this atrocity into the pre-production pipeline… Maybe you should stop. Or maybe the rest of us, the movie-going, sci-fi loving, “Terminator” adoring public have to be the ones to say it. “This ends here.”

There is nothing about Terminator: Genisys that suggests that this film was a compelling, urgent, essential dream for anyone involved. This is all about squeezing cash out of people who are fond of the original films, calculated and without any of the soul of Cameron's films.
One achievement of James Cameron’s “Terminator” is that it overcame its low-rent, B-movie trappings. The great sin of “Genisys” is that it costs millions and yet isn’t worth a dime.
What could anyone have said of the finished film except that it was finished? Terminator Genisys plays like the worst of all outcomes.

Terminator Genysis is basically a dumber and more convoluted film than Terminator 3. The film either retreads old ground or gets entangled in a convoluted story for the sake of resetting the timeline. There are elements of characters in the form of a hardened Sarah Connor but it’s never explored enough as the film gets way too bogged down in explaining the plot. Just when it seems like the film is dipping its toe into original territory it boils down to the exact same climax we’ve seen a million times. The film ends with our characters driving off down the road knowing for the first time in their life that they are free to choose their own path. Hopefully that’s what the next Terminator will do.

Terminator: Genisys has it's entertaining moments, but the story is far too confusing and weak for it to matter. The premise was intriguing, but the trailers revealed too much, and watching the film had few surprises. The script was a major weakness of Terminator, because it left things unexplained, revisited way too much old material from previous films, and was way too overly complex. Along with the story, the dialogue was at times forced, and tried to remind us of older, better days, for the franchise. While the script wasn't very good, the action sequences were very good, and the actors were serviceable. Unfortunately the very confusing, sometimes unexplained story weighs the entire film down, and the end result is a mediocre film.

I completely disagree with the negative reviews. Frankly, I don't understand them at all. Emilia Clarke was perfectly cast as Sarah Connor. She brings a certain innocent vulnerability to the role that makes perfect sense in the context of the plot. Jai Courtney, while not ground breaking, delivers a solid performance as Kyle Reese. Jason Clarke was outstanding as John Connor and delivers a thoroughly enjoyable performance and often steals the scene. Arnold is Arnold, take that as you well. The references and jokes regarding the previous films were enjoyable and appropriately delivered without being done. The action was good, but more importantly the plot was better. I've seen people say the plot is convoluted, but I completely disagree. It's no more complicated than Inception and is a perfectly legitimate story given the context of time travel. J.K. Simmons' character Detective O'Brien wasn't really necessary and could have been removed, BUT his presence in the story makes total sense. Overall this was actually quite well written and thoroughly enjoyable. It is completely faithful to the original two Terminator films and SIGNIFICANTLY better than the crappy Terminator: Rise of the Machines and Terminator: Salvation. If you enjoy the Terminator franchise and wanted to see it done justice, this film should certainly please you. 8/10.
I thought that Terminator Genisys was great. I liked how nutty the plot was. Arnold was awesome and Emilia Clarke is fantastic. Very cool movie. The critics have been too hard on this one.

“Terminator Genisys” directed by Alan Taylor is the fifth film in the Terminator franchise and sixth in the mythology if you include the cancelled TV show “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” that ran from 2008-2009 on Fox.   While the film is not bad per se it is not great either feeling like another rehash of the same old material.  If you count the TV show this is now the fourth time the main purpose is to stop Judgement Day and destroy Skynet.  This is the inherent problem with the franchise and the reason it should have stopped after “Terminator 2: Judgement Day”.  How many times can we watch the same story told over and over again?  To make matters worse the plot of the movie borrows heavily from “The Sarah Connor Chronicles”.  I feel the series staple of time travel is used to excess in the film.  The cast is full of some of my current favorites doing their best to go through the motions on this retread.  Emilia Clarke brings her usual strength in a small package that serves her well on “Game of Thrones” to the role of Sarah Connor.  She strikes an excellent balance between the young T1 Sarah and the harsh chiseled Sarah of T2.  I do appreciate a quick joke in the film about her small stature since she stands just over 5’1” in real life and the rest of the cast towers over her.  Jason Clarke really does well with John Connor in the opening act of the film in 2029 but his character somewhat comes off the rails in the latter half of the film.  Jai Courtney, as Kyle Reese, keeps getting roles despite having no chemistry with anyone he is ever in a movie with.  He brings none of the soul that Michael Biehn brought to the role 31 years ago.  For you “Doctor Who” fans blink twice and you’ll miss Matt Smith, billed here as Mathew Smith, in a smaller than I hoped for role that carried a lot of importance but didn’t get a lot of screen time.  Also fresh off his Oscar is J.K. Simmons who maybe hadn’t won his Oscar yet when he filmed this because I didn’t even know he was in it until the opening credits rolled.  As for Arnold Schwarzenegger reprising his role as the titular terminator there isn’t much for him to screw up here.  The motion capture they used for his younger self is much better than it was in “Terminator Salvation” and the reason for him appearing as old as the actor is in real life fits perfectly in the narrative of the film.  While the film tries to recapture some of the emotional beats of T2 it comes up a little short and instead focuses on rehashing the same two jokes with his character the whole movie.  In the end if you are asking to see it, rent it, or skip it, it really depends on you the viewer.  If you are a big Terminator fan that would enjoy a nostalgia trip through the first film or are just looking for a decent popcorn flick then see it in the theater.  For everyone else I say rent it.  You won’t be missing much even if the Mother of Dragons is in the movie.  There is a mid-credit scene so don’t get up and leave once the credits start.  It is very brief but once you see it you can go.  There is nothing at the end of the credits.

Was I entertained? Yes. There were some enjoyable echoes of the original Terminator film throughout this one, which worked well. But as its own film, it really struggles. First, I didn't care about the characters: too many chases and actions scenes; not enough effort to put complex characters in the story. Second, I think the franchise is just out of ideas. The first two films are classics; but this, like the previous two mediocre sequels, feels like recycled plot and action from the earlier movies. Instead of standing on its own as a new story, it tries too hard to prod nostalgia while trying to keep the door open for more Terminator movies down the road. A tough balancing act. Add to that a lot of plot holes and time-travel logic knots, it's hard to walk out of this with more than a smirk and shrug.

The writing is really spotty and the film seems to be relying more on a lame romance than the action that wins over the audience. Terminator Genisys is a complete disappointment.

Ranting levels critical, you’ve been warned: So today I went to see the 5th installment in what was once an amazing franchise, who’d have thought that they could sink any lower than Terminator 4, but they can in this spectacular fail of a movie. At no point did anyone expect this to be any good, the trailer saw to that but I don’t think anyone could predict how bad it truly is. There are no adequate words but I’m gonna go for it anyway. So Arnie is back (in his many forms) to do what he does best, except this time he’s called Pops, now if this wasn’t a warning bell it pretty much explains why the rest of the movie was so terrible. Not only is this film horrifying on its own but it has to take Terminator 2 and in particular Terminator 1 and drag it through the dirt. It can’t even establish itself as anything new, taking great scenes from the classics and rehashing them hoping the fans will be too caught up in the moment to notice. It singlehandedly destroys the first two Terminator movies and leaves us with this horrendously traumatizing and soul crushing sorry excuse for a movie.

John Connor sends Kyle Reese back in time to protect Sarah Connor, but when he arrives in 1984, nothing is as he expected it to be. The events in Genisys act as a ripple across an alternate universe. What if Skynet got to John Connor? What if a T800 saved a younger Sarah Connor? What if Judgement Day took place in 2017 instead of 1997? Yes there will be plot holes, but with this much fun who cares!

Now in it's fifth instalment the Terminator series, Arnold has returned once again in another attempt to stop the seemingly unavoidable judgement day from happening. But sadly at this point it feels as if the franchise has been back too many times. It fails to bring anything substantially new and instead feels more like a weak rehash of things we've already seen in previous films.

"Terminator Genisys" suffers two major problems. First, it does not know how to spell "genesis". Second, the quality of the story and character development is literally scraping the bottom line while production values for all the explosions and **** are blown to epic proportions. This seems to be a consistent issue with a lot of blockbuster reboot movies, as they all tend to bring in previous senior cast members (or popular, trending new ones), let them act out on a bland script with the most preposterous plot twists (I won't spoil anything, but there is a twist to the movie, and boy do these twists go far beyond), and use the rest of the money on car chases or huge fights that involve a lot of, you guessed it, explosions. "Terminator Genisys" is no different from the others, so the question remains; is this predictable movie really worth your green bills?
Basically just another cliche loud dump fun pop-corn movie sequel that offer nothing but fun and that's it , it's not even deserve the "terminator" name in the movie title.
horrific    horrific   horrific   horrific horrifc   horrific horrific    ,  at the beigging it was ok    but  later in the movie its horrific  absolutely    horrible    ...  just horrifc

Not a sequel, not a remake, not a reboot... this film is something new, reinventing the story while it stays true to the original film as well... The result is a new story making you feel like you discover the first movie again... great great fun, especially for die hard fans of the franchise.

Not a bad film to waste away a wet and dreary Saturday afternoon.  Plenty of action but the confusing plot brings it down a few pegs.  It's a mash of the old and the new - despite some of the other reviews Arnie definitely adds to the movie, he's like a comfortable armchair - you know what to expect from him, nothing less and nothing more.  6/10 is still a good score and if like the series you'll enjoy it.

It certainly can not be compared to the first two Terminator movies. But it is quite ok. Not as bad as the critics seem to suggest. Acting is horrible, almost comical, but that may not be an important part of this movie anyway. Emilia Clarke's performance was very disappointing, especially knowing that she has talent.

Old but a little obsolete. The latest Terminator entry gets good grades for effort, but ends up with mediocre results. This reboot works because of Arnie, but didn't work because of the younger casts.  Emilia Clarke is great in Game of Thrones, miscast as Sarah Connor. The plot line has some smart moments, but sometimes felt like a 'parody' of the Terminator series.  Even its action scenes were remixes of better set pieces from part 1 & 2. It's worth a look, entertaining in parts but simply too convoluted for its own good. The production team tried their hardest, but simply cannot match the inventiveness of James Cameron's much superior original duology.

When even a liquid killer bot seems to have more personality than the male lead, I guess we should start to worry. Arnold steals the show as a grizzled Terminator protecting yet another version of Sarah Connor in several timelines from several killer bots and the viewers from crying from boredom or confusion. You got to give him the credit for at least making this movie watchable.

What is there to say really. They're cashing in on Arnie's and the Terminator franchise's popularity. The casting choices are all very bad and basically put popular/pretty actors in roles they don't fit. The plot is a big giant mess. But I will still gave this a 6 because the action is fun, and it's great to see Arnold reprise his classic role.

The way "Terminator: Genisys" was promoted was unacceptable, the trailer spoiled the film by giving some major details that should not of happened.The film tries to do something that the franchise have never done before but it's confusing on the other hand and that's what the film is going for, but it has a good idea trying to destroy Skynet before it's start a revolution between humans and machines, it's sounds good right?  The script is so convoluted filled with plot holes and it barely makes any sense, obviously the film is written by people who don't care for the franchise. The film has lackluster action, that's odd because the terminator series has great action scenes, director Alan Taylor does a slick way of directing the action scenes and copying off of James Cameron. John Connor (Jason Clarke) the leader of the human resistance, sends solider Kyle Reese (Jai Courtney) back in 1984 to protect his mother Sarah Connor (Emilia Clarke from 'Game of Thrones') from another terminator assassin, creating an unexpected turn of the events in the timeline; in the first Terminator Sarah is a scared waitress, but now she is a skilled fighter and has her Terminator guardian (played once again by Arnold Schwarzenegger) by her side. With good allies and dangerous enemies Reese sets out on an unexpected new mission: reset the future and prevent Skynet from launching their app before the robot apocalypse starts and destroys mankind. There are many flaws with the movie, Arnold once again is great and brings so much energy and like ability into the Terminator and Jai Courtney was missed cast however he was fine playing Kyle Reese. Emilia Clarke was missed cast as Sarah Connor (she can act but not in this movie) she over does with her performance and Jason Clarke was not a mediocre version of John Connor like Nick Stahl, Clarke can act but doing over doing it as the John Connor character. The film is not cheesy or cliche'd it's confusing as hell and the action is mediocre. Grade C-
+ Very enjoyable action scenes

"Terminator Genisys" is a great return to form for the time traveling franchise, even James Cameron himself praised this as the true successor to his films. "Genisys" while not as brilliant as the first two films, is a vast improvement over the 3rd & 4th movies. Arnold Schwarzenegger proves he is still capable of pulling off being a Cybernetic Organism and steals every scene he is in & both Emilia Clarke and Jason Clarke gave surprisingly good performances as Sarah Connor and John Connor though i will say that Jai Courtney won't win any new fans as Kyle Reese. The action was really fun on a big IMAX 3D screen and I enjoyed this a lot more than Jurassic World mostly because the characters are much better.

Technically well made, big action and spectacle as expected, and Arnold in a welcome return is just fine.  The problem is the movie is so confounded with time travel in a story that is mainly retread disguised as reboot sequel that it doesn't make much sense.  There are plot holes and flaws.  One small one in particular I wondered about is with the filmmakers going through all the trouble of recreating 1984 Los Angeles, with beautifully shot/VFX of the downtown skyline of that era for example, then go and blow a simple detail like LAPD using a collar radio instead of a walkie talkie in that year.  A very small flaw yes, but it amounts to sloppy direction.  And that amounts to a befuddling story with too much action and not enough well thought out plot in a movie that drags despite the strong franchise base and fun that it has with it.

Another instance where the user reviews are more indicative of the quality of the movie than the "professional" reviews. I didn't expect much going in to see this, but the story was a lot stronger than i had expected.. makes me want to go back and re watch the originals. Worth a watch despite what the critics are saying, i don't even know why or how critics exist in this day and age where everyone is a "critic" , their opinion is no more valid than ours, only difference is we can't be bought. If you like the originals give this one a chance.

Terminator Genisys is like the A Good Day to Die Hard of Terminator movies. It's all action and not enough brains. Which is a shame since it had some good casting. IGN said Emilia Clarke was miscast as Sarah Connor but she is perfectly tough and badass.

My mom could portray a better T-800 than Arnold does in this film, with his cheeky one-liners, gray hair, and--and WHERE exactly did he come from, anyway? And in what timeline does a terminator go back to 8-year old Sarah Connor? There are so many timelines flying around, AND YET, despite sort of comprehending what that means, the script STILL insists that there's a Judgment Day and someone has to go back and stop it. Never mind the current theories in physics.

Not a fan of Jason Clarke as John Connor and Emilia Clarke looks to young and fragile as Sarah Connor but this new reboot is exciting. Yes, we have deep changes on Skynet's timeline and John happens to be the villain but follow this story is as entertaining as in the past. T-800 rules and makes as laugh with his gained humanity, Kyle and Sarah have a funny love story and action sequences are very good. How not to like this? Many questions remain but they will surely be answered in the next films of the franchise, which I can't wait to watch.

Terrible film i got very confused from start to finish the plot was all over the place i really didnt enjoy what i was watching arnie is past his sell by date ill be be back nah dont think so,it didnt even have that terminator feel to it well i was dissapointed and the acting didnt help either worst of the terminators films actually t3 is much better than this and it was crap but not as crap as this people with taste should avoid.
This movie isn't great, but neither is it as bad as some reviews would have you believe.
A solid action film in general, better than 3 and Salvation but not on par with 2. Some unnecessary soppy scenes but altogether character progression was ok.

An utterly ridiculous parody of itself, this is a stupid but somewhat enjoyable film. Arnie delivers some excellent one liners, and there are so many in jokes for fans of the franchise, you can't help but laugh along. Clarke does a good job filling some very big shoes, in spite of generally woeful dialogue, and the storyline, whilst ludicrous, is compelling enough to keep the audience interested. There are some great action sequences, and the underlying cautionary tale resonates for a contemporary audience moving inexorably towards an 'internet of things', making for a fun yet unpolished experience. 5.87/10

Terminator Genisys isn't as bad as everyone is saying. I actually really enjoyed the film. Although the confusing plot drags it down a little bit, and it sort of feels like an omen to the first two Terminator films, its still a fun action adventure that fans of the Terminator franchise will love. Also, to finish this review off, Arnold is fantastic! His new catchphrase will be one to remember... but I won't spoil it for you.

By watching this film I felt a longing, because those times were my times :) Arnold turned in 200% of their character. Terminator Genisys( not spelled how it sounds) is a fun movie. But it's not the kind of movie you watch for to in-depth story, because in my opinion the story feels a bit all over the place. Like it couldn't decide which story it wanted to tell, so it frankensteined all their idea's together into a bit of a jumbled mess.

An enjoyable action film which at times is seemingly a parody of the Terminator franchise (a good thing!). Arnold is back and delivers an extremely entertaining performance full of cheesy one liners and some very active fight scenes! Some greatly humorous throwbacks to the original film during the scenes in the 80s which at times almost felt like you were watching an 80s flick. CGI Arnold returns albeit briefly in an apparent stab at Salvation which I enjoyed and the plot was quite interesting. More modern scenes were quite accurate in their portrayal of our current obsession with being constantly connecting and the Windows 10 esque operating system was interesting. John Connor delivered a fantastic performance and really made you fear the character at times, while Matt Smith's performance similarly shone out towards the end of the film. Overall, a slightly cheesy and action-orientated film but not one that deserves the bashing given by critics. Certainly will be enjoyable for fans of the series and an interesting take on the Terminator franchise!

To the so called Critics that review this film, allow me to quote a famous Terminator line by the Arny man himself, **** you ****  Why you might ask, because too much early witch hunting BS went down about this film.  Arnold does wonders for this film, giving credit to the character, the director a new approach to the film and yet classy to the Cameron feel of how the future is portrayed.  If anything that can be criticized was the studio company giving away too many plots too early in the marketing of, "Terminator Genisys", and the fact to have James Cameron talk about it to help endorse it.  As Arnold stated, "The director did a fine job and it seemed that the studio wanted to get Cameron to endorse the film."  Along that context.  The only thing that besides too early of plot marketing of the film was also of the fact that too many details and give away's were leaked in the marketing giving a bad taste to the expectation of the film.  Emilia Clarke is good in her performance of Sarah Connor, and the rest of the cast as well.  The film gives excellent humor in the film if also homage to the catch phrases that made the franchise memorable.  The only downside for the film itself is the idea of speeding the story a little too quick at certain points but at the same time too throw in some mysterious plot points related to Arnold's character itself.  But while the slight mystery plots were potholes only at minor areas.  The film itself makes up in overall story, action, and an exciting roller coaster.  To the fans supporting this I quote, "Excellent!"  To the critics rating this movie at Metacritic, allow me to add an additional quote and misleading the fan base totally, "Chill out, Dick-wad!"
I really liked this film. I didn't have high expectations but I was surprised. Some parts were dumb and it wasn't amazing but it's defiantly worth seeing
real good idea behind the script, good acting , i ve pass a great time watching it !!!! 8/10. taking some old and remix footage of the first movie was really a good twist of nostalgia!!!!

There are two major problems with "Terminator Genisys": One -  the movie is a lie to its own franchise and timeline. Two - its plot has a shotgun hole as huge as the shotguns in the "Teminator" series are usually capable of inflicting.

Alan's style for movie making shows that he likes making movies about heroes and we are waiting for Good movies from him.

Another soulless and brainless entry into a series that has already been ruined twice before. There is no originality here, it is just a mishmash of bits from T1 and T2. Horrible script and uninspired acting throughout. Emilia Clarke wasn't terrible as Sarah Connor hence the 1/10 as opposed to the 0/10 it truly is. Arnold is relegated to being the bumbling old idiot and the magic is unfortunately gone from him. J.K. Simmons makes a nice cameo appearance but everyone else is just living in HAM city. Do not support this rubbish, I feel awful for simply renting it.

Terminator series are always the best and that includes genisys. I went to watch it in cinema with low expectation but it was actually very good and really enjoy it. I cannot say anything bad about it at all. Manipulated timelines, non stop actions and i guess this is the end of terminator with a great ending. I hope they leave it at that, no more.

Well damn, this film is great, I enjoyed a lot of parts of it and surprisingly enjoyed Arnold as well.

I went in with really low expectations but quickly got into it within the first 10 minutes. The biggest problem was the spoilers in the trailer. If for some reason you haven't seen the trailer, don't.
Don't get all the hate and low ratings.
This is my new favorite Terminator. It feels like it executes/expands on the dream that was The Terminator.Don't bother watching the trailer. Just go see it.

Honestly, I think that this one's getting a little too much of a bad rap from the critics. The only reason I can think of that they're bashing this movie so hard is because they're probably setting their expectations for it waaaaay too high and possibly even expecting it to be as good as the first two films. If that's the case, then they have no one to blame but themselves for not liking this film, because it was never meant to be as good as the first two films. Those films are are masterpieces and this one was just meant to be a fun and entertaining action flick, which it was. And of course, it wouldn't be a Terminator film without Schwarzenegger himself in it (unlike the previous film, which threw in a cheap stunt double version of him), so it's good to see him in this. Overall, yes it has its cheesy and ridiculous moments (but what action flick doesn't nowadays?), and yes the writing and dialogue aren't up to par with some of the previous films, but at the end of the day, this was just a fun film and that's all I wanted out of this film. If you go in with that same mindset, I'm sure you'll enjoy it.

Don't believe the critic's  for a minute - Terminator: Genisys doesn't disappoint.  The problem is that when it comes to these summer tent pole movies,  they always want to see something totally new and groundbreaking in terms of effects, which - to be fair-  this movie really does not do. OK- so the shape - changing Liquidmetal T-1000 Terminator in the film can't re-capture the magic of seeing it for the 1st -time 25 years ago in T2 ( it's like seeing Lightsaber's again in the Star Wars Prequels, no big deal, right? ) - nor does the new actor ( w/ is never explained ) upstage Robert Patrick's T-1000 - which would have been a real nice touch if they used his likeness in this movie ( they scanned him into the computer in 91 - so I don't know why they didn't? - ) but this film thankfully doesn't hang on that.  This new film was Way better than T3:, which was nothing more than a boring retread of T2- and didn't advance the story at all. You could skip it ( this new film does) and you wouldn't have missed a thing. Compared w/ this new take/ twist/ re-write of the timeline, T3 is lame. The original film now also  seems just outright dull compared to this flick. Do I believe the original actor's from the original were better? Yes, maybe they were?  But having said that - I didn't dislike the new cast at all. It's a different take, as this Sarah has lead a different life. This was easily the 2nd best Terminator film to date. It was far better than JJ's 2009 Re-boot of our beloved Classic Trek.   Genisys is only one of three movies I've watched in the theatre over the course of the last year -and I will be going to see it again.

After all that hate this movie rieceved after the trailers and some...'strange' reviews.I went in with low expectations.Having watched it a few hours ago i can clearly sau iw as surprised positively. EMilia Clakre as young sharah is  very good, jason Clarke is OK , Courtney is a bit dull and Arnold is hands down once again fantastic.

Terminator Genysis is not hate-worthy or praise-worthy. It entertained me while I was watching and by doing that I guess it got the job done. However, the plot is very loosely written and the acting is mediocre except from Arnold who is perfect in the role yet again. 6/10

If you've come to see another sequel to the Terminator you came to the right place. If you came to see Who's afraid of Virginia Woolf you need to check your ticket. I think this was one of the best installments of the series and I'm one picky SOB.

After seeing the Metascore of 39/100 my expectations were LOW. haha  Maybe, that's why I thought the movie was PRETTY DAMN GOOD!  It's not a 10(I just gave it that score because of these RIDICULOUS underscores).  This movie is a SOLID 77/100.

WOW I will start by saying that I really enjoyed this movie. I mean out of the 5 movies I would rank it 3rd. I would say #1 is T2 and #2 is the original and the last 2 are up for debate. I will start with the story which is the hardest part to grasp as it combines all of the movies and mixes them up. I mean they go through 3 different time periods so I will say it was an alright story plot for the fact that they did mix it up from the original formula. I will move onto the acting. I mean Arnold is a Beast like always and as for Sarah Connor who is played by Emilia Clarke from GOT I thought she felt out of place compared to Linda Hamilton. We also have Jason Clarke as John who I personally loved. I will finish in the acting department with Jai Courtney as Reese who I thought did a decent job considering he had to fill Michael Biehn's shoes which is almost Impossible lolz but he did a good job. I will finish with the action department and say that it was Fantastic and the CGI was used to perfection I thought. I also loved how they incorporated the T-1000 for a little while. I mean it had that Nostalgia that brought me back and I loved that for sure. I would also say that the movie had a decent amount of humor. I will now close out with saying that if you're a Terminator fan that you should definitely go and watch this movie. I would also recommend watching it in IMAX 3D because that is what I saw it in and it made it all the more EPIC.I can only hope and pray that they come out with an Unrated version of the film when it comes out officially on Blu-ray and DVD.

this version is completely lazy, ill thought out and horrid, they absolutely wrote out the last three terminators to come up with a movie so convoluted on its own nonsesnse that it takes a huge dump on the entire franchise
Very good movie, if you are science fiction fan, alternate realities, androids growing into humans, lots of action... Arnold I must say played the terminator role very well.
SPOILERS

Great old school action movie! Hilarious Arnold and well-played Emilia Clark as Sarah Connor made the movie! Old tricks such as battle between Reese and T800 and new ones such as Arni with T1000 like hand are fantastic!
I enjoyed this film. one of the best terminator i have ever see. nice cgi, arhold is back, realy nice story. you realy have to check that out.

Very glad I did NOT watch any trailers beforehand.  In fact I barely remembered this movie's existence until right before driving to the theater.  So because of this I very much enjoyed the twists(though they were obvious).

Genisys is a complete mess, from its plot to its characters. It lacks any intelligence or thematic elements that made the first two masterpieces and, more importantly, it's not that fun. While it was good that Arnold was back in his T-800 form, Emilia and Jason Clarke, usually great actors, are completely miscast as Sarah and John Connor. The CG, however, is terrible. I was skeptical from the trailers regarding this film, and I was not disappointed. This film sucks and was a waste of my time and money. Hopefully they cancel any kind of sequels in place, because it already has killed the franchise.

I feel like the critics didn't even watch the movie. I would say this movie, T2 and ESPECIALLY (well the first 30 minutes of..) Terminator 1 make a perfect, awesome trilogy. The action and casting of Sarah Connor is so spot on, along with some interesting casting choices for John and Kyle but they work. The action and Terminator 1 on 1 combat is beyond anything the past films have done, it's stylish, it's violent and it's intense. The story is no more convoluted than anything Christopher Nolan has done, it makes perfect sense if you pay attention to the film and not a little notepad nit picking the entire film. Don't listen to the critics! Please! Movie goers will love this, even if just to see Arnie kick ass one more time!

I very rarely rate a film a "failure"; yet even though "Genisys" is  from a beloved, brilliant franchise it fails so badly, I couldn't wait for it to end. This film is the worst I've seen all Summer. I didn't shell out the bucks for 3D or IMAX, and was so pleased I went that route. It fails in large part due to the writing. The script muddies the waters so badly that nothing, not even Arnold's performance, can survive the maddening confusion that continues to build to the very end of the film. Yes, the CGI is good, but it too is weakened by the frustrating story line. The support characters are played by good actors, but like Arnold, they are washed out by the terrible script. If you must see it, wait for the cable release.

Loved the movie and so did my brother and his family. Arnold Schwarzenegger did a fantastic job as the Terminator once again even bringing back the one liners. To me this movie felt like a  sequel to reboot the franchise once again if they decide, something similar on what X-Men of Future Past did. A must see if your a Terminator / Arnold fan, however if you do watch it, sometimes the story can get complicated with time travel, but just enjoy the movie for what it is and a open mind.
Please, don t pay attention to critics!! they get payed to say something is good or bad.

It's the casting that destroys this movie. Whoever cast this movie crippled its chances of being any good. It might have been a five out of ten if they'd been able to get actors who were a decent approximation of the original characters, but Emilia Clarke, Jai Courtney and the bloke who plays John Connor are terrible, terrible choices.

Honestly better than I expected with all the horrible reviews its been getting. The movie really suffered from giving away too much in the previews. It would have probably been best not to reveal the bad guy in it as its supposed to be a pretty big emotional scene for the characters in the movie and it lost alot of impact because of it. And while the story took quite a few convoluted twists and turns, especially with the alternate dimensions stuff, it did ok in the end. Emilia Clarke does an excellent job in her first big movie role and Arnold does really good in the movie, with a few old timer jokes thrown his way for good measure. Jai Anthony really needs to stop getting these kinds of roles as he's always too stiff and rigid compared to the rest of the cast. I didn't like him in the Die Hard movie and I especially don't like him here. It's getting to a point to where I'll avoid a movie if he's in it cause I know he's going to be terrible. However there's enough good here to satisfy even a passing fancy in the terminator universe, but it should be noted that it's not going to be for everyone. It was a good time for me and my friend and that's all that mattered for me in the end.

I really enjoyed Terminator: Genisys, I think it compliments both the first and second film which I really liked a lot, and it explores the storyline in a much more different way this time in comparison to what the normal storyline is - that's not to say that the characters goals have changed of course.
Suddenly a worthy sequel

WHHHYYYY SO HATE????? this movie was great. arnold was as usual great. CG is great. cast is great. emilia clarke was superb. the movie never gets boring. this movie is criminally underrated by the F U C K I N G critics....

This movie is like what "HATRED" is to video-games (but then without the controversy part) or in other words a disappointment, the only good thing about this movie is Arnold's performance, which in all honestly isn't really worth watching it for, as he doesn't appear as much as he should to keep you interested.

For the first time since T2, there's a terminator film that is emotionally resonant, fun, and smart enough that my brother and I are still talking it over and proposing theories. I usually cringe at the sloppy way sequels call back to previous films, but this one did so very well. Instead of using awkward call-backs as a crutch, they were smoothly integrated in the film and not only had a natural feel, but they also helped to launch the plot forward. The writers went in interesting directions with the story, and the dialogue and action were both solid.
Here's the deal. Ignore the 'critics'. If you enjoyed Terminator and Terminator 2, buy a cinema ticket and go and watch Terminator Genisys.

Read a review from some moron claiming one would need a degree on quantum mechanics to understand the film. Ridiculous, I had no problem. The plot is not hard to follow, it's simple if you just pay attention to their dialogue. I made a point to watch the original Terminator prior to viewing this film and was amused to see them recreate the scenes in which both Reese and 1984 T-800 arrive by time travel. The film was geniunely thought out and written quite clever. If one has a problem following a very simple plot, then go back to school, it wasn't hard to follow at the least. Brilliantly entertaining, and throws around an astounding theory that time, no matter if the past is changed, or the future, it is still linear. Loved this film, love the franchise. 10/10
Despite Emilia Clarke's performance, this Terminator is NOT as bad as critics or people make it out to be.

The story leaves a lot to be desired.  Having an older T800 Arnold definitely seemed as though there was no better alternative, and it felt like many chunks of the plot were taped together to make the movie work.

If you love Terminator movies, this will be worth seeing. If you love action movies, this is still worth seeing. If you want to see an amazing story with great lines and great acting across the board, skip this one.

Terminator Genisys may not top the first two films, but it is stupid fun. This approach to the franchise, and with Arnie back, Director Alan Taylor aims for the bare minimum Terminator movie, and yes, this is way better than Salvation. Jason Clarke gives a hammy performance as John Connor, but he is enjoyable, with a great story to tell, Clarke pumps life into Connor once again, one thing that Sam Warthingon couldn't do in T4. The opening sequence consists of a war between machine and man, one thing that this series has been all about' but if you really want to experience Genisys, I suggest you watch the film in the large format theatres, so you get the big picture, believe me, it's amazing. Emilia Clarke is good as Sarah Connor, as well, but is she as good as Linda Hamlinton in T2? No. But man does she try! But the holy grail of the pack, is Arnie! Holy crap, does this guy still have that swagger and bravado that made him The Terminator. He is a powerhouse on screen, the whole theatre started clapping during his one liners. Genisys has problems, it's way too long for an average action movie, and it's disappointing. It's not as good as I thought it would be, the teasers made it look special and top the three movies before it, not counting McG's disaster. Terminator Genisys is not a disaster and fans will love it for the action and Arnie.

What can I say about this film?  As soon as the movie started I wanted to rip my eyes out and shove them up my a** and that still would've been more enjoyable than watching f***ing piece of crap.  This movie is a disgrace to Arnold Schwarzenegger and shows that he shouldn't be acting anymore.  Dear god, don't see this movie, in fact, the director should be burned at the stake for making this abomination of a film.

When you have the urge to go to the theater to watch Genisys, get up and orientate yourself towards the direction of your DVD shelf, use your Terminator-like scanning abilities to eye up Terminator and Terminator 2, pluck them purposefully from their neglected dormant state and have a good night in, you deserve it.

It's even worse than you might fear. A lazy, repetitious, one-trick gimmick masquerading as a film, with lame jokes, no character to speak of, terrible dialogue, and some truly horrendous casting. And that's just for starters.

It wasnt bad, but it wasnt amazing or anything Spectacular. I have forgotten whether I have watched the previous Terminator series. But, after watching Terminator Genisys, it made me want to watch the previous series too. That's all I can say.

Amazing movie!  Ok so I expected this to be good at best but being a huge terminator fan i had to see it anyway. So me and my girlfriend go watch it and we are both blown away! We agree this was our favorite terminator movie of all time. Dobře odvedená práce. Po vlně kritiky která se na tento film vznesla, musím za sebe dodat, že jsem se velmi dobře bavil. Arnie je sice stará páka ale hláškoval jak za mlada, příběh celkem ušel i když se jedná především o těžkou popcornovku a výběr rolí také nebyl zcela od cesty. Začátek byl naprosto perfektní v půlce to trošku začalo zpomalovat aby to ke konci nabralo plný plyn. Jsem velmi mile překvapen, jak to celé dopadlo, jen mi tam chyběla obvyklá scéna s brýlemi. Ano, když chce člověk psa bít, hůl si vždy najde a kdybych chtěl, mohl bych to vlastně celé strhat, ale mě se fakt nechce. Opravdu jsem se bavil a to i přesto, že to byl jeden velký digitální trip a věci byly mnohdy přitažené hodně za vlasy. Za hlavní plus považuji, že mě to doslova vrátilo časem.

This has to be one of the greatest films I have ever seen. I honestly cannot see why people do not like it. It's got amazing action scenes, an amazing story, good acting, and most importantly it's got Arnold. This is the best movie I have seen all year. I really hope it gets a sequel.

This movie is mindless, entertaining fun. If you're expecting a Judgement Day level of thoughtfulness, then you'll definitely be disappointed. I was just looking to be entertained and on that point I was thoroughly satisfied. I'd definitely recommend this movie.

I'm not entirely sure, if I saw the same movie the critics have seen. What I saw was a fun bombastic summer blockbuster that was a love letter to its origins, and a mostly refreshing take on an old series. After watching the first two Terminators (3 and Salvation were decent to mediocre at best) a plethora of times, I was somewhat worried what the outcome of a third attempt at a sequel would bring. The threat of an omnipotent Skynet in the form of Genisys was a great idea to push this battered series back into relevance. Plus the action was top notch, and Emilia Clarke was looking as gorgeous as always. Arnold did a stellar job as well, putting as much humanity one can in the boots of a soulless killing machine. Jai Courtney's performance completely surpassed my expectations as well and had great on screen chemistry with both Jason Clarke and Emilia Clarke. The time travel aspects weren't overly complex and were perfectly reasonable considering the massive amount of dissonance in time already caused by the first two movies. The movie is without a doubt worthy of a solid 8.5 for just the astounding set pieces and Arnold Schwarzenegger alone. Jame Cameron was 100% on point when he stated that this movie is the true sequel to Judgement Day. So my recommendation is to ignore the critics and watch this movie with an unbiased view point and you'll have an absolute blast.

I can not describe to you the amount of script holes of this movie. It tore the whole premise of the franchise. It's a beautiful piece of ****. Stay home, place Terminator 2 on your DVD player and save money movie.
Terminator movies are like pizza - even a bad Terminator movie is good.  Unless, of course, it is rancid and spoiled.  I saw this movie in IMAX 3D on opening night and ended up terribly disappointed.

If you enjoyed T1 and T2 (why wouldnt you???) then you'll most likely enjoy this movie like i did.  I watched it yesterday and was really surprised how well the movie handles the different time travel, alternate timelines so that it actually makes sense. Emilia Clarke owned her role. Arnold didnt say much, but the few funny lines and gestures he provides are classic Schwarzenegger. Great action scenes, although i wouldnt recommend paying extra for 3D- it looked great, but the movie did fine without it.

Full disclosure - I'm the guy who enjoyed Terminator: Salvation, so make of that what you will. After reading the reviews, I was surprised by how much I actually enjoyed this film. The story has some plot holes (and at least one major unanswered question), but even if its script can't hold a candle to the second movie, it's certainly not the least-well-written Terminator film (that would be T3: Rise of the Machines). The effects are suitably cool and the actors are suitably cast. If there's one thing that Arnold S. actually can act like, it's a robot. Perhaps that's the picture's biggest crime - it's just suitable rather than phenomenal. It could be said that the Terminator franchise is like a rock band that peaked with their second album and has never recaptured that perfect sound. But that doesn't mean they don't put out decent records every now and then.

How many Terminators does it take to make the right one? We will never know because they're all the same film being duplicated over and over again, remixed like a one hit wonder. Just as there are different versions of the Bible; they all say the same thing just like Terminator Genisys is repeating itself with another updated version. If you enjoy reruns as a fan then you will reunite with your childhood robot toy for your last goodbye.
Arnie and Emilia were great but story was not believable. I quite enjoyed watching it but could not get rid of a constant underlying sense of disbelief.

I have only one word for this movie: s**tbuster. Guys the first Terminator movie was a serious one, since it was quite more an horror than a sci-fi. An unstoppable killer come from the future. It's just a "hey look! come to see a whole new Schwarzy movie! It's just it. The Expendables with machines.

a franquia exterminator do futuro acabou em 1992, com uma obra prima dirigida e escrota por james cameron, depois veio exterminador 3 que ate tem algum sentido mas aimda assim um filme ruim, depois os direitos de exterminador fiacaram girando e rodamdo em varias maos ate sair exterminador a salvaçao, que ate tenta ser inovador, mostrando como é o futuro de john connor e seus aliados, mas mesmo com toda essa tentativa de mostrar algo diferente foi um filme mais ou menos. agora nas maos da paramount e da skydance, saiu o exterminador genisys, um filme que nao se leva a sério em algums momentos, por exemplo no ínicio do filme, o roteiro nos leva de volta 1984, no mesmo ambiente do primeiro filme, o que deixou muito empolgado todos os admiradores da série, mas depois de um até entāo bom primeiro ato, temos um roteiro bagunçado que não sabe, o que fazer com a história do filme, mesmo com o avassalador marketing das produtoras e arnold fazendo muitas coletivas de impressas e varios eventos, nao ajudaram a levar o público para esse filme que nem ao menos devia existir, esperemos entâo até 2019, ano que os direitos desta franquia de ( dois ótimos filmes ) volta ao criador james cameron.

The Nostalgia: As an avid (rabid...) fan of the first two movies, and having rewatched them (yet again) shortly before seeing Genisys, I was expecting and consequently looking for references to the first two films. They were plentiful, and many were subtle. Some major events, such as the scene in the trailer where Sarah rescues Kyle Reese and the old T-800 versus the new T-800 were obviously not subtle. But they were awesome to watch, to remember those moments from T1 and see how they've changed their path due to more time traveling events since T2. The less subtle ones were enjoyable as well, however. And I don't think the average watcher of Genisys will catch even half of the subtler ones (such as a thumbs up from the old T-800 to Sarah Connor-- this is the last thing she saw of the Arnold's T2 character, as he was lowered into the steal; as well as throwbacks to T2's Terminator arm.

I would have liked this movie a lot better if they didn't turn John Connor into an evil person. Couldn't they come up with another villain and another angle on the story? For instance, seeing the same familiar story change completely because of one thing disrupting whatever happened in a previous movie, giving the same set of circumstances a completely different outcome the heroes have to overcome. I did like the operating system angle. That almost accomplished an interesting angle until John turned bad. So many other more interesting angles could have been used. But, as usual, the effects are great and the movie was entertaining, except for the bad John. Jason Clarke is excellent, but I want him to stay the hero. Our technology being the villain where people misuse it would have been a better focus. That would be very thought provoking because it could happen.

Pobre James Cameron, Genisys no es solo tediosa, sino también confusa, aburrida y poco llamativa. La trama es tan incongruente que destruye por completo la historia de Terminator y Terminator 2, forzando una historia "nueva" para crear una trilogía. Obvio que si la película es mala, el guion lo es, los diálogos son absurdos y poco entendibles, las secuencias de acción son monótonas, los efectos especiales son lo "poco destacable" aunque no es lo mejor en efectos especiales, las escenas se ven bien. Las actuaciones son decentes (Emilia Clarke hizo lo que pudo, estuvo bien, aunque no pudo con la original sarah Connor) y Arnold Schwarzenegger puede presumir que ya tiene lo necesario para formar parte de "Los Vengadores" (chistes ridículos y diálogos estúpidos) En general, Terminator Genisys es solo una película palomera y ya, no esta al nivel de Mad Max: Fury Road o Jurassic World, recomiendo verla en formato DVD o Blu-Ray si es que tienen la curiosidad de verla.

It's a great welcome to see Arnold Schwarzenegger back into real actions after so many guest appearances in other films but the main idea of the overall film leaves an impression of manipulating the time-travelling in X-Men: Days of Future Past, solely an easy way to reboot the entire franchise without a proper story line. Less darker than the other four installments, several twists are easily predicted and there is obviously a number of flaws and time paradox when the story progresses but the film is still an entertaining generic sci-fi. The scores of the film composed by Lorne Balfe are rather weak even though co-produced by Hans Zimmer, the performance of Jai Courtney as Kyle Reese is just alright, Arnold as T-800 is still the most entertaining element of the franchise with his fights and adorable robotic expressions but the pacing of the script has caused the lack of emotional engagement with Sarah Conner (Emilia Clarke). James Cameron says that this film is respectful to his first two installments back in 1984 and 1991 but action sequences are nothing new, CGIs do not improve much from previous installments and the visual effects seems a bit video game setting have overall disgraced his compliment.

I said it before and Im gonna say it **** MOVIE CRITICS!Not everything they say is right,for Christ sake,Metacritic gave Predator like 3/10 rating and that movie is a Classic with a capital C!This movie is far far better than that piece of **** salvation its not even up for a debate and yeah its far better than the third one Rise of the Machines which I kinda liked tbh its not that bad.Genisys offers you practically everything.There are many funny scenes like the one when Sarah,Kyle and almighty Arnold get caught on the bridge by a police and that police dude says Arnold to get down on his knees lmao and when they have taken their mug shots and that bad boys song comes on,Arnold grins and Sarah is too short for a mug shot.HILARIOUS!And when Arnie tells Sarah and Kyle almost at the end of the movie how he worked in Skynet as an employee but he got fired,after he says he got fired he crushes the door and that gives you an answer why he got fired lmao that was funny as **** movie has nice emotional scenes wih Sarah and Arnold too bad they didnt show more scenes of Arnold and Sarah in their beginnings when she was a kid,their moments…Some action scenes were meh but only like two,first one when that t1000 is driving to the truck and instead Kyle uses that m203 grenade launcher immediately he keeps on shooting at t1000 with bullets,that was kinda weird but ok.And maybe that bus scene was too exaggerating.J.K Simmons did his job but he should have been more on screen and given more character history…Effects were great and at one scene you thought you were watching Star Trek or something.The movie IMO is 8/10 but the lowest rating should be something like 6.5/10 or 7.

I was very much disappointed with the movie. This is second worst in the franchise. The storyline is completely with plot holes and there is no chance that they can make any changes to it in the next installments.The VFX looks like PS4. Emilia Clark as Sarah Connor was a bad impression on Linda Hamilton's character.The VFX of T-1000 looks no different and nit advanced and looks same as T2 which was almost 20 years back! Arnold was the best thing in the whole movie. Jk Simmons character had a good potential and was wasted. The war scenes looked great better than salvation. As a true Terminator fan, having seen each movie and the 3D show at Universal, I can say this movie is average. This movie doesn't tread along the lines of mediocre, yet it lacks what made Terminator so good. It feels as though it was made by Michael Bay. Too much explosions and action to make it what made Judgment Day the best. The CGI was definitely worthy and good. Bad at some moments during action sequences, but overall it was brilliant. Yet it ruined the movie a slight, because it gave the movie less of a real feeling. The helicopter flying was obviously CGI and in Judgment Day, the helicopter flying was REAL. That's what made those scenes so good, was the fact it was REAL.

And again, don't listen to the critics. Terminator Genisys is indeed a fun movie to watch. It is a gift to the fans that contains a lot of inside jokes and unexpected moments. We had a great time watching this movie!
IMHO -> nothing special. Good special effects, but simple story and horrible John Connor and Kyle Reese destroyed that movie. Waste of time. Unfortunately.

I thought Terminator Genisys was great! Several times in the film they pay homage to T2 and the plot was tight and quick paced - the visual and sound effects were impressive! The terminators look awesome. There are plenty of eighties throwback lines and guns and ammo you loved from old Schwarzenegger films too. The acting was sharp with some nice laughs thrown in so it doesn't take it self so seriously. Also kudos to Hollywood for making it PG-13 so it's more family oriented. Keep it classy. A big applause to director Alan Taylor (The Sopranos, Game of Thrones) and bringing in "Khaleesi" to play Sarah Conner (babe alert!) - significantly cuter than Linda Hamilton. And more chill. No offense. The movie also makes some good social commentary on the use of technology. Today most of society is plugged  in (smartphones) and theirs not much real connection going on between friends and family. It's important to realize we have a short time on earth - make the most of it! This film was an action packed race for humanities future and I look forward to the next two in line!

The central Sarah-Kyle dynamic gives it a much stronger emotional core than 3&4 too, which is why I like it so much.

Genisys offers some attempts at stretching the story and modernizing the Terminator series in a way that had never fully been realized before.  Salvation will feel like a distant memory here as the darker post-apocalyptic feel has been traded in for a more modern-day action flick.  While it has its moments of fun action, I couldn't help but feel like Genisys is trying too hard to be an Avengers movie that effortlessly channels moments of humor and cleverness into the potential end-of-the-world giant that is the story.  On top of that, the seriousness rarely felt that serious.  Partially because of the writing, partially because of the casting.  Arnold is fine, but the casting choices for John Conner and Reese seem wrong in hind-sight.  Neither quite fit into their role, making me wonder why the director and casting crew felt compelled to move forward with both.  There are missed opportunities within the expanded story as well - the new face of Skynet offered such a fantastic opportunity to make Terminator more than just a bit of nostalgia.  This could have been more on the level of Inception, but it isn't.  Alas, Genisys is just another cog in the wheel that is a franchise that has really shown its age.  Terminator 3 may stand as the weakest of the movies to some, but Genisys isn't all that much better (if at all).  Should they find reason to make another one, they'll have a helluva lot of rubble to dig through to clear the name.  Perhaps it would be better if they left it alone?

Its ok, its not great and its not bad. The good news is, they got the future war scenes down right. Shame there was only 15 minutes of the future war. However, the actor they got to play Kyle Reese was not suited to the role. His stale and lifeless acting would have better been suited to the role of the t-1000.
I gave it a 4 because it was good enough to be watchable due to nostalgia. I would advise anyone thinking of watching this movie to make sure they have watched the first 2 Terminators first.

A sequel/reboot to the franchise that ultimately fails to capture the magic of the originals. The magic of the time-traveling, sci-fi series isn't quite captured here as the story and changes to the timeline go under-explained. As a result, the whole thing feels convoluted. At least the action is solid.

As sequels go this is one of the poorer ones out there. Ignoring the last two instalments this tries to change just about everything from the first two films, and becomes so confusing its hard to keep up, and even harder to care. A spectacularly bland lead trio don't help matters with Jai Courtney starring in yet another franchise killer. Made for purely financial reasons before the rights revert back to James Cameron, this is cynical filmmaking with no heart

It's an OK movie but i would separate it from the whole Terminator franchise It is overcomplicated with things  that are unnecessary and instead of simple story like in T1,2,3,4 we get something really complex in terms of story with a lot of comical reliefs on the top. The problem is that the script writer had no idea how to close holes in the script so instead of simplifying it he used thing like "we just don't know lol. For example the main question of the film - who sent Pops back in time? What was the answer? "This information is deleted from my memory". I mean they leave it there just like that and don't do anything with this story hole. This is terrible. On the other side visuals are very good i like it but i couldn't get rid of the feeling that i was watching Fast & Furious 2029 instead of Terminator.  It looks good but at the same time it's dumb as **** and it has nothing to do with the original. I think i can clearly say that the movie was saved only by the appearance of Arnold. Without him the movie would be a complete disaster.

Although the movie didnt have the great story and acting of the first two movies - this movie was far superior to the third movie and the fourth movie. Something i never saw coming, the characters didnt fit their roles, they didnt ACTURATELY portray sarah connor or kyle reese, allow me to explain. In the original terminator, kyle reese was DEFINATLEY a soldier by the way he acted and spoke but the 2015 portrayal of kyle reese was so bad he seemed to be some ordinary joe trying to survive attacks from killer cyborgs. And sarah, i must say that linda hamilton did a great job of her portral of the mother of legendary soldier john connor, she truly set the standard for that character, thats why when i saw the new version of sarah connor and how they wrote her character, i was thouroghly disgusted! She wasnt strong, she was angry! She wasnt fierce, she was just a **** a TOTAL **** who acted more like an uppity feminist with a chip on her shoulder! Now the story/plot, its not bad but mainly confusing and for them to shuffle john connor off to the side as if he doesnt matter anymore and basiclly put kyle in the spotlight as he's now the future savior is just wrong to me! Well, this is embarrassing. While I am an enormous fan of the first two "Terminator" films and while this particular film does try rather hard to sully a lot of the lore within those original pieces, I can't really say that I didn't enjoy it. In fact, there is a good amount to enjoy in this film (Yes, I know). From the brilliantly designed set pieces, to the commendable attempts to develop characters whilst commenting on current societal trends, "Terminator Genisys" is actually not all that bad. It's just all a little muddled and confusing upon further reflection.

This is a classic example of film critics having a nostalgic attachment to source material (i.e. the first two Terminator films) that's not as great as they remember it being. I have enjoyed all of the Terminator films, but none are great. Examples: 1) There is no believable, meaningful "connection" between Sarah Connor and Kyle Reese in the first film, due to bad acting and even worse dialogue. 2) T2 may be a somewhat better film but it also suffers from some poor acting/scripting/directing (e.g. there's this awkward Sarah Connor voice-over, narration device that gets introduced out of nowhere about halfway through the film-- assuming it was done in order to match tone with the first film?). T3 was forgettable, but not awful.

Not the best adaption to the terminator franchise. TWhile Arnold is back and better than ever, this movie uses the same tired old characters from the previous adaptions but with half the heart of the others. While it does have some interesting sequences and scenes plus a bunch of great Arnold scenes, it ultimately does nothing to invigorate the franchise and ultimately screws up the timeline in a bad way more than good. This movie was lazy film-making in almost every way, instead of breathing life into the franchise the franchise further pushes the franchise back to the dark ages. If they hope to truly reinvigorate the franchise then they need to take lessons from where Jurassic World succeeds and go to new places with different characters and retire the John/Sarah Conner and Kyle Reese arc.

Terminator Genisys is not a complete dud and I will say it’s better that it’s predecessor Terminator Salvation, but that  doesn’t change the fact that this film is quite a bit of a mess. I’m not angry I’m just disappointed. It has a plot that basically makes you go “what the hell?” for an hour and a half and basically acts as too many re-makes of Terminator 1 & 2 that don’t really work unless you have actually seen those two!  I’m not really a fan of these re-imagining versions of the characters, there is a whole lot that is not really explained and it won’t really warrant repeat viewing because it will only work  to further hi-light the amount of plot holes in this film and there’s tons of really heavy handed we rely on technology too much messages in the film.  Apart from Matt Smith’s rather interesting turn as a villain for this film, there is not really that much memorable here and I suspect this one will be cast aside to the cusp.  Terminator has become like Highlander in that anything that came after it, they only got a brief stint at being very good and everything that followed, has sucked.  This film keeps up the tradition.  The action scenes are very decent, but they are very repetitive and the film’s effects really vary in quality, not to mention the acting isn’t entirely par.  I especially did not like Kyle Reese in this film and what they did to John Connor was almost inexcusable.

To have seen Arnold in 1984 on the big screen was amazing.  He was Mr. Olympia, and to imagine him as an unstoppable killing machine was terrifyingly believable.  What if he came to your door?  As with all the movies of that time, Star Wars, Rocky, Indiana Jones, etc, no one expected there would be sequels.  That's something Hollywood dreamed up later.  So here we have number 5; how do they make it different but still the same?  The basics are still the same, the machines take over the world, but sending Kyle back in time to save John Conner's mother has a twist.  And there are more twists to come.  Most of them don't really make sense if you analyze it logically.  But hey, this is an action movie, fighting, shooting, blowing stuff up, and Arnold, of course.  "I'll be back" became quite a catch phrase back in 1984.  Who knew he'd be coming back 30 years later?
I really don' get the poor reviews for this movie. Going into this movie I expected hard core action, and I got it. No spoiler here: Old Arnold met young Arnold, and the CGI was second to none.

Terminator Genisys is an action lovers action movie. It stands out among the Terminator films in its ability to understand the Cameron formula. It only takes itself seriously in its telling of the alternate timeline, which it projects admirably. Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jason Clarke, Jai Courtney, and J.K. Simmons handle themselves and each other with beautiful conviction, while Emilia Clarke is somewhat subdued in the lackluster role she portrays-she appears to be the weak link. Writing, music, production, and direction are on point while costume is no more or less than general, yet, precise. The parallels to the human condition are poignant, yet not overtly dramatized. All in all this is a fun flick with true popcorn potential. Enjoy your refills!
